article_title: History is not on Brady's side for sweeping tax reforms
article_text: To continue reading this story, you will need to be a digital subscriber to HoustonChronicle.com.

article_metadata.description: "The challenge is, does he take a 'K Street' mentality of tinkering around the edges, or does he use the opportunity as head of Ways and Means to push some wide-ranging, sweeping reforms?" said Dan Holler, of the conservative group, Heritage Action for America.  The pressure Brady faces from the GOP's tea party wing reflects the deeper divisions between Republican leaders and "outsiders" like presidential candidate Ted Cruz over the sweep of conservative reforms that they consider achievable under the currently divided government with President Barack Obama.  The tax code has become far too complex and far too larded with tax credits, subsidies and other benefits that essentially require higher marginal rates in order to recover the revenue necessary to run the government.  [...] while Cornyn, Brady and other congressional leaders appear resigned to a practical legislative agenda in the upcoming presidential election year, conservative activists who see themselves as the bedrock of Republican power in Congress find little to gain from holding back.  Backers of the worker tax credits have sought to apply early pressure by pointing to the estimated 61,000 families in Brady's district who benefit from the earned income and child tax credits for low-income people.  Some see the makings of a modest budget compromise by combining the business and worker tax credits as part of a must-pass comprehensive 2016 spending bill.  Brady has not signaled his negotiating stance on the upcoming spending bill, but he has made clear that another major building-block of his tax plan is to reduce the tax hit on corporations' overseas earnings.  The other test, according to Doggett: Will it help small businesses or further slant the playing field favoring those who hire the most powerful lobbyists and sign the biggest campaign checks?  [...] far the GOP tax agenda has failed on both counts.
article_metadata.author.name: By Kevin Diaz
